thread.title: Manchester United are hard to beat but draws just won't do for Jose Mourinho if they're to climb the table
thread.title_full: Manchester United are hard to beat but draws just won't do for Jose Mourinho if they're to climb the table

author: David McDonnell
title: Manchester United are hard to beat but draws just won't do for Jose Mourinho if they're to climb the table
text:
Sport Opinion Manchester United are hard to beat but draws just won't do for Jose Mourinho if they're to climb the table United, who remain in sixth place, are still four points off fourth-placed Liverpool and Manchester City in fifth Share Manchester United's Wayne Rooney after a missed chance (Photo: PA) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
This must have felt like Groundhog Day for Jose Mourinho and Manchester United . 
Dominate opponents, lay siege to their goal, only to come away empty-handed and racked by a sense of what might have been. 
United, who remain in sixth place, are still four points off fourth spot, held by Liverpool , who are ahead of Manchester City on goal difference. 
Since being hammered 4-0 at his former club Chelsea in late October, Mourinho has steadied United, whose unbeaten run in the Premier League stretched to 14 games with this draw. Jose Mourinho sits on the touchline as he watches his side turn in another draw (Photo: Julian Finney) Paul Pogba looks dejected during his side's goalless draw (Photo: REUTERS) 
The problem for Mourinho and United is that draws are simply not good enough if they are to have any chance of wrestling free from sixth spot and making a concerted push for a top-four place. 
Mourinho may have turned United into obdurate opponents who rarely lose, but it is wins they need, or the Europa League may end up being their best route back into the Champions League. 
Mourinho made nine changes from the side that cruised past Wigan 4-0 in the FA Cup at the weekend, Marcos Rojo and Henrikh Mkhitaryan the only players to keep their places. 
This was the fourth occasion these two sides have met this season and the third in three weeks, following their EFL Cup semi-final double header, in which United prevailed. Substitute Rooney remonstrates with referee Mike Jones (Photo: REUTERS) Phil Jones limped off injured during the second half (Photo: Getty) 
Hull began the night rooted to the foot of the Premier League table, wins the previous night for Swansea and Crystal Palace, and a point for Sunderland, leaving them at rock bottom. 
Tigers boss Marco Silva made six changes from the line-up that made a meek exit from the FA Cup, losing 4-1 at Championship side Fulham last weekend. 
Five points from safety and with Liverpool and Arsenal up next, survival is already looking beyond Hull, with time and games running out for them to stage an unlikely escape act. 
The visitors found themselves under pressure straight away, Ander Herrera picking out Henrikh Mkhitaryan after two minutes, Andrew Robertson foiling the latter with a last-ditch tackle. Pogba reacts after Eldin Jakupovic pulls off a great save to foil him (Photo: Manchester United) 
Having lost 2-1 at Hull in the second leg of their EFL Cup semi-final a week ago and scraping through on aggregate to reach the final, United were in no mood to suffer the same fate here. 
They played with purpose and penetration right from the off, with leading scorer Zlatan Ibrahimovic forcing a fine save from Eldin Jakupovic with a long-range effort after 14 minutes. 
From the subsequent corner, Rojo headed over the bar, after Marcus Rashford had flicked the ball back into the danger area. 
It amounted to a bullish start from United, with Hull pinned back in their own half for much of the first half-hour, adopting a policy of containment. Zlatan Ibrahimovic holds off David Meyler (Photo: Getty) 
That approach was tested to the limit with United's relentless pressure, Jakupovic again coming to his side's rescue just before the break, after a swift attacking move from United. 
Michael Carrick picked out Ibrahimovic with a sweeping ball, the forward's instinctive flick setting Paul Pogba through on goal. 
United's world record £89million signing looked destined to score, but Jakupovic managed to palm his goal-bound effort behind, thwarting United once again. 
Mourinho sensed he needed to change things around and brought on skipper Wayne Rooney for Carrick at the start of the second-half, with Herrera dropping deeper. United's Portuguese boss cuts a frustrated figure (Photo: Clive Mason) 
Rashford wasted a glorious chance to make the breakthrough in the 55th minute, applying an exquisite first touch to Pogba's fine ball, then scuffing his shot wide. 
Ibrahimovic then steered a shot wide of the target after Rooney had missed the ball completely, with the home fans sensing the elusive goal would not come. 
Oumar Niasse, who had been booked early on for a foul on Rojo, was lucky not to receive a second yellow for a late lunge on Blind, and was subbed soon after for his and his side's welfare. Oumar Niasse could have been sent off for Hull (Photo: Getty) 
Jakupovic's heroics continued with a remarkable save from sub Juan Mata, who had the goal at his mercy in the 73rd minute, but somehow saw his shot smothered by the Hull stopper. 
With five minutes to go, Lazar Markovic could have sealed a dramatic win for Hull, but his clipped effort hit David De Gea's right-hand post and bounced to safety. 
Abel Hernandez could also have won in at the death for Hull, after being put clean through by Tom Huddlestone’s lofted ball, but he shot tamely at De Gea. poll loading Will Manchester United finish in the top four? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
